0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-idUSKCN0ZN090	Trump rejects criticism
column2: vents at news media in campaign speech	"

column1: By Steve Holland
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump on Wednesday rejected criticism of his campaign tactics
column2: in a wide-ranging speech defending his team's use of a Jewish star and his own praise of the late Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein.At a campaign rally in Cincinnati
column3: Ohio
column4: Trump vented his frustration at a news media he feels is out to derail his candidacy and help Democratic rival Hillary Clinton
column5: deriding CNN
column6: in particular
column7: as the ""Clinton News Network.""Trump's hour-long performance was unlikely to reassure those Republicans who would like to see the New York businessman focus his message on attacking Clinton to rally the party behind him at the Cleveland convention from July 18 to 21 where he is to be formally nominated.He was particularly animated in defending his campaign's use of what was seen to be a Jewish star in a tweet last week that described Clinton as corrupt. The star was replaced with a round emblem after the criticism
column8: but the incident has generated days of controversy.Trump said he thought the star was more the shape of a sheriff's badge. He described as ""sick people"" those in the news media who called it a Jewish Star of David.

column1: Later
column2: Trump tweeted an image of character from a book linked to Disney's movie
column3: ""Frozen""
column4: that used a similarly shaped star on its cover.""Where is the outrage for this Disney book? Is this the 'Star of David' also? Dishonest media! #Frozen
column5: he tweeted.

column1: In his Ohio speech
column2: Trump also returned to the subject of Saddam after generating controversy on Tuesday by complimenting him for his handling of militants.Irritated by the criticism
column3: Trump brought up Saddam again.""So I said bad guy
column4: really bad guy
column5: but he was good at one thing: Killing terrorists... I don't love Saddam Hussein. I hate Saddam Hussein. But he was damned good at killing terrorists
column6: Trump said.

column1: Trump also reacted to a mosquito that buzzed near his hand at the podium.""I don't like mosquitoes
column2: I never did. Speaking of mosquitoes
column3: hello Hillary
column4: how are you doing?"" he said. (Reporting By Steve Holland; Editing by Clarence Fernandez)"

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-money-idUSKCN0ZM24M	Donald Trump
column2: Republican Party boost fundraising in June	"

column1: By Ginger Gibson and Alana Wise
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Donald Trump and the Republican National Committee raised nearly $51 million for his presidential campaign in June
column2: after he launched his first aggressive effort at raising cash
column3: Trump's organization reported on Wednesday.The most recent haul dwarfed the $3.1 million the Trump campaign raised in May. That low number prompted widespread concern among Republicans that the New York businessman
column4: a newcomer to politics who largely bankrolled his primary campaign
column5: would be unable to compete with Democrat Hillary Clinton's massive fundraising operation.For June
column6: fundraising emails circulated by the Trump campaign attracted $26 million
column7: in addition to more than $25 million raised in conjunction with the RNC through joint fundraising events in June and the last week of May. The joint funds are intended to help both Trump and candidates in other races
column8: such as people running for Congress
column13: bringing the total contributions for the month to about $55 million.""We just started our fundraising efforts in the last week of May and we are extremely pleased with the broad-based support in the last five weeks for the Trump Campaign and Trump Victory
column14: the campaign said in a statement.In June
column18: including $40 million for her campaign and $28 million for the DNC and state victory funds. She began July with $44 million in cash on hand.While Trump's June total far eclipsed the candidate's past hauls
column20: a Republican fundraiser who worked for Mitt Romney in 2012 and raised money for Jeb Bush in the 2016 primary
column21: said the dollar count was much lower than the $106 million that Romney
column23: brought in during the same month four years ago.""This is his low-hanging fruit
column25: I'm not putting it down. But it needs to get much better than this quickly. He's playing a game of catch-up right now

column1: Clinton's fundraising advantage has allowed her to build a vastly larger campaign infrastructure.Clinton already has extensive staff operations in the most important battleground states and has begun to run paid advertising. Trump has only a handful of staffers and has made no large television ad purchases.Trump beat 16 rivals in the Republican presidential race
column2: but his free-wheeling style and some of his campaign pledges
column3: such as his plan to build a wall on the U.S.-Mexico border
column4: have long worried some in the party establishment and he has struggled to unify Republicans behind him. CLINTON'S SUPER PAC ADVANTAGE

column1: The Super PACs supporting Trump
column2: which are permitted to raise and spend unlimited sums but are not allowed to coordinate directly with the campaign
column3: have also struggled to get organized. While there was once a constellation of more than a dozen Super PACs backing him
column4: most of his support has consolidated around Great America PAC
column5: which is being run by veteran political operative Ed Rollins.The PAC is on target to raise $10 million before the July 18 start of the Republican National Convention
column6: said Eric Beach
column7: a top PAC official. They have already seen an uptick in fundraising
column9: doubling the May haul of $2.5 million.Great America PAC is using that money to run television ads
column10: and plans to attack Clinton over her use of personal email servers during her time as secretary of state.The Super PAC supporting Clinton
column12: had raised $88 million by the end of May and had $51 million to spend. The group is already running ads attacking Trump.

column1: Trump got off to a slow start in fundraising
column2: funding much of his primary campaign with his personal wealth in loans that totaled about $50 million. He announced last month he would forgive the loans to his campaign
column3: intending to signal to potential donors that he would not use their funds to repay himself.He held his first fundraiser in late May and had several in June
column4: including a high-dollar event in New York City and several fundraisers in Texas.Trump continues to promise to make contributions to his own campaign. In June
column5: he launched an online fundraising effort by promising to match donations up to $2 million.Trump and Clinton both use joint fundraising agreements with their respective parties.The agreements allow the candidates to accept checks larger than the $5
column6: 400 limit that an individual can give to a campaign. Instead
column7: the larger donations are divided up among the campaign
column8: the national party and various state victory funds. All the money is then used to help elect the presidential candidate as well as other candidates.The campaigns and the political parties are permitted to coordinate how they spend that money. (Additional reporting by Michelle Conlin in New York and Emily Stephenson in Washington; Editing by Frances Kerry and Peter Cooney)"

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-health-congress-opioids-idUSKCN0ZM2LG	U.S. Republicans reject Democratic funding proposals for opioids	"

WASHINGTON Republican lawmakers in U.S. Congress on Wednesday rejected two Democratic amendments to provide nearly $1 billion in funding for bipartisan legislation intended to combat America's opioid epidemic
column2: aides said.The rejection
column3: which came during a meeting of U.S. House of Representatives and Senate negotiators on the measure
column4: could undermine Democratic support for final legislation that could come up for a vote in the House of Representatives as early as Friday. The House and Senate each passed its own versions of the legislation in the last few months.House and Senate Democratic lawmakers are now withholding their support for the final version of the bill
column5: according to two Democratic aides.Democratic opposition could prove to be an obstacle
column6: especially in the Senate
column7: where lawmakers need 60 votes to move legislation forward.

column1: Two amendments
column2: from House and Senate Democrats
column3: would have provided $920 million up front to finance program grants for states. Aides said the programs otherwise require completion of a lengthy appropriations process that could stall in a congressional session shortened by this year's election campaign.

column1: Republican aides were not immediately available for comment. But House Republicans are separately considering a health spending measure that would provide more than $581 million to address opioid abuse.House Democratic Caucus Chairman Xavier Becerra said on Wednesday it was only the latest instance in which legislation with bipartisan backing fell short on funding. ""It's becoming a bit of a joke to say we're concerned and want to do something
column2: when the only thing we'll do is shell of what it actually takes
column3: he said.

column1: (Reporting by David Morgan; Editing by Diane Craft)"
3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-runningmate-idUSKCN0ZM1ZZ	Two leading Republicans shy away from being Trump's VP pick	"
By Susan Cornwell and Steve Holland
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Republican Donald Trump's list of potential vice presidential running mates got a little shorter on Wednesday when one prominent U.S. senator withdrew from consideration and a second said she wanted to focus on her home state.The moves by Bob Corker of Tennessee and Joni Ernst of Iowa could complicate Trump's efforts to rally establishment Republicans behind his presidential bid.With Trump looking at a self-imposed deadline of July 15 to announce his pick
column2: there was no indication that the wealthy businessman was anywhere close to reaching what is perhaps the most important decision he will make as the presumptive Republican nominee.Trump is looking to announce his running mate just ahead of the Republican National Convention
column3: to be held July 18-21  in Cleveland
column4: where he is expected to become the party's official nominee.In Cincinnati
column5: Ohio
column6: on Wednesday
column7: Trump campaigned with potential vice presidential candidate Newt Gingrich
column8: a former speaker of the House of Representatives who is popular in conservative circles.Introducing Trump
column9: Gingrich tried out the role of the No. 2 with a robust attack on presumptive Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton for her email practices
column10: on the same day the Justice Department decided not to levy criminal charges over what the Federal Bureau of Investigation called her ""extremely careless"" handling of classified information when she was secretary of state.""There are two Americas. There's the corrupt Washington of the old order. And there's all the rest of us. I say to you

column1: Trump liked what he heard.""I'm not saying it's Newt
column2: but if it's Newt
column3: nobody is going to be beating him in those debates
column4: Trump said. Trump told Fox News he has 10 candidates on his vice presidential list
column5: including two generals. One source said Indiana Governor Mike Pence is being pushed internally by some members of Trump's inner circle. A former congressman
column6: Pence met with Trump on Saturday.Corker
column7: from Tennessee
column8: who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee
column9: had wrestled privately over whether to be a contender for the No. 2 position
column10: telling friends he had never been a surrogate for another politician.

column1: Corker spent eight hours at Trump Tower in New York on Tuesday
column2: then campaigned with Trump in Raleigh
column3: North Carolina. He told reporters he withdrew because ""I just felt like I was far more suited for other types of service.""""You know
column4: it's a highly political role for the next four months
column5: he said. ""I view myself as deep in substance and policy
column6: and I just think there are better ways for me to serve in the public arena.""His withdrawal eliminates an important party establishment figure as Trump tries to broaden his appeal with plans to visit Republicans in the Senate and House on Capitol Hill on Thursday.

column1: Corker's withdrawal could be considered a canary in the coal mine with establishment Republicans who are convinced that Trump cannot stay on message and can't stay focused on attacking Hillary Clinton without doing some type of damage to his campaign
column2: said Republican strategist Ron Bonjean.Some Republicans felt Trump erred by not taking full political advantage of FBI Director James Comey's statement on Tuesday that Clinton mishandled classified emails.In Raleigh
column3: Trump sharply attacked Clinton but strayed from the message by saying the late Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein had done a good job cracking down on militants.Ernst
column4: a rising figure in the Republican Party
column5: spent part of the Fourth of July holiday on Monday meeting with Trump.She seemed to be leaning against the vice presidential position
column6: and told Politico
column7: ""I made that very clear to him that I'm focused on Iowa. I feel that I have a lot more to do in the United States Senate. And Iowa is where my heart is."" (Reporting by Susan Cornwell and Steve Holland; Editing by Toni Reinhold and Leslie Adler)"

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-aides-idUSKCN0ZM2MU	After FBI report
column2: Clinton aides could find it harder to get security clearances	"

column1: By Arshad Mohammed and Jonathan Allen
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON The FBI's harsh criticism of Hillary Clinton's use of a private email system as U.S. secretary of state could make it difficult for some of her closest aides to keep or renew government security clearances
column2: but it would not affect Clinton herself if she is elected president
column3: experts said.Federal Bureau of Investigation Director James Comey said on Tuesday an FBI investigation had found evidence that Clinton
column4: now the presumptive Democratic presidential candidate
column5: and her aides ""were extremely careless in their handling of very sensitive
column6: highly classified information"" at the State Department. Comey said he would not recommend that the Justice Department bring criminal charges - a recommendation accepted by Attorney General Loretta Lynch on Wednesday - but the FBI director noted that people found to have been similarly careless often face consequences in the form of ""security or administrative sanctions."" Most administrative sanctions
column7: anything from a reprimand to a dismissal
column8: can't be imposed on Clinton and three of her closest aides Cheryl Mills
column9: Jake Sullivan and Huma Abedin as they have already left government
column10: experts of the government's classified information regime said.But legal experts said that if Clinton aides were found to have treated classified material with extreme carelessness that could give the government reason to consider denying them a security clearance in the future or suspending or revoking one they may currently have. ""If the system is fair and equitable
column11: then they should all have difficulty maintaining or obtaining a security clearance in the future
column13: a Washington D.C.-based attorney who specializes in national security matters.Steven Aftergood
column14: a Federation of American Scientists expert on national security and classification policy
column17: that Comey had highlighted what he called a problematic security culture at the State Department. ""So it might be hard to penalize individuals for this episode if their entire agency embraced similar practices
column18: Aftergood said. A Justice Department spokesperson declined to elaborate on Comey's statement
column19: which did not name any of the aides. The Clinton campaign did not respond to questions about the security clearances of Clinton
column22: nor did lawyers for the three aides.

column1: Abedin
column2: who has been a personal aide to Clinton for about 20 years
column3: and Sullivan
column4: Clinton's policy director at the State Department
column5: sent information the government now says is classified to Clinton's unauthorized private email account
column6: according to email records released by the State Department.It remains unclear if they sent any of the 110 emails that Comey said contained information that was classified at the time they were written. The only author of such emails he identified was Clinton herself.A small number of other department colleagues sent  information the government has since marked as classified to Clinton's account less frequently
column7: the records show. The government forbids handling classified government secrets outside secured channels it controls. Clinton has said she did not knowingly send or receive classified information through her private email server.Both Abedin and Sullivan now hold senior roles in Clinton's presidential campaign and are widely expected to join a Clinton administration if she is elected on Nov. 8. Mills
column8: who also passed along information the government now deems classified
column9: has continued to work as a lawyer for Clinton but has no formal role in the campaign. It unclear if she will seek a role in a Clinton administration.

column1: SENATE BLOCK?
Some presidential appointments require Senate confirmation
column2: and lawmakers could use any past criticism of an aide's handling of government secrets as a reason to block their appointment to a Senate-confirmed job
column3: said William J. Leonard
column4: a former director of the federal government's Information Security Oversight Office.The State Department declined to discuss individual cases and said that as a matter of policy it does not publicly disclose who has a security clearance. But it said it can apply security sanctions
column5: such as putting a black mark on a person's permanent personnel file that would come up in future background checks
column6: even against former employees.

column1: For those former officials who maintain an active security clearance
column2: they could lose it.""Department policy is to maintain files on personnel who are found to have mishandled information to guide current and potential future decisions about employment and security clearances
column3: John Kirby
column4: a department spokesman
column5: said in a statement. Without knowing precisely what the FBI found about the actions of specific Clinton aides
column6: it is impossible to say what  effect there may be on their current or future security clearances.Paul Ryan
column7: the House Speaker and the most senior elected Republican official
column8: said on Wednesday that Clinton should be denied the security clearance required to receive the customary intelligence briefing that government officials give to presidential nominees before the election.Presidents and other elected national officeholders are not required to have background checks to receive government secrets
column9: according to experts and the Central Intelligence Agency.""It would roil our system of representative democracy if a security official could say that the president ... can't have a security clearance
column11: an attorney with extensive experience in security clearance matters. (Reporting By Jonathan Allen and Arshad Mohammed
column12: editing by David Rohde and Ross Colvin)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKCN0ZM0U1	Clinton visits Atlantic City boardwalk to hit Trump on casino bankruptcies	"
By John Whitesides
| ATLANTIC CITY
column2: N.J.

column1: ATLANTIC CITY
column2: N.J. Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton visited the famous boardwalk in Atlantic City on Wednesday to highlight Republican rival Donald Trump's casino bankruptcies
column3: warning he would bring the same cutthroat approach to managing the U.S. economy.Clinton
column4: standing next to the shuttered Trump Plaza casino that Trump once owned
column5: said the real estate developer routinely profited from the financial ruin of workers in the economically depressed seaside resort town.""The people he's trying to convince to vote for him are the same people he's been exploiting for years - working people
column6: small-business people
column7: Clinton said.Clinton said Trump's casino bankruptcies and numerous complaints against him by contractors showed he cannot be trusted to set economic policy from the White House.""He makes over-the-top promises and says if people trust in him
column12: and Donald gets paid.""The Trump Plaza was one of four casinos Trump once owned in Atlantic City. He left the city after his last bankruptcy.Clinton frequently uses criticism of Trump's business record to illustrate a principle campaign theme - that the wealthy New Yorker is only interested in boosting his financial bottom line
column13: and not concerned about the economic struggles of working Americans.Clinton reminded supporters who gathered on the boardwalk under a boiling sun
column14: within steps of the city's beach
column15: that Trump had promised to ""do for the country what I did for my business.""

column1: She said Trump intentionally ran up hundreds of millions of debt on his companies
column2: borrowed at high rates
column3: defaulted on the loans
column4: and left in the lurch the workers and contractors who relied on his casinos for income.""That says everything you need to know about Donald Trump
column5: Clinton said. ""It's not about what he can build. It's about how much he can take.""ECONOMIC STRUGGLES

column1: Atlantic City has struggled economically in recent years as a series of casinos have closed. The city's 10 percent unemployment rate is nearly double the national average
column2: and closed buildings pockmark its boardwalk.In an emailed statement
column3: Trump defended his bankruptcy filings on casinos and other projects as a commonly used practice to restructure a business and ultimately save jobs.""I created thousands of jobs and made a lot of money in Atlantic City
column4: which was what
column5: as a businessman
column6: I am supposed to do for my company and my family - and as President I will make America rich again
column7: he said.""Nobody understands the economy like I do and no one
column9: will do more for the economy than I will.""

column1: After the speech
column2: Clinton drove a few blocks to shake hands with dozens of striking workers outside the Trump Taj Mahal
column3: another of the casinos that Trump once owned.Her attack on Trump's business dealings came as the presumptive Republican presidential nominee blasted her integrity following an FBI report that criticized her use of private email during her tenure as secretary of state.Clinton did not address the email issue during her stop in Atlantic City.On Tuesday
column4: FBI Director James Comey said the agency would recommend no criminal charges against Clinton for her use of private email servers. But Comey rebuked her for what he said was ""extremely careless"" handling of classified material on her email servers
column5: and contradicted her claims that she never transmitted or received classified material on that email system.Republican lawmakers criticized Comey for what they saw as lax treatment of Clinton
column6: and on Wednesday
column7: committee chairman Jason Chaffetz
column9: announced that Comey will testify before the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee on Thursday to explain the bureau's ""surprising and confusing"" recommendation.The FBI has been investigating whether Clinton broke the law as result of personal email servers kept in her Chappaqua
column11: home while she was secretary of state from 2009 to 2013
column12: including whether she mishandled classified information on the servers. (Additional reporting by Alana Wise in Washington)"

column3: for example

By Patricia Zengerle

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-ryan-idUSKCN0ZM1MB	Ryan says Congress considering action on Clinton's email use	"
By Susan Cornwell
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON U.S. House Speaker Paul Ryan on Wednesday said lawmakers are examining whether there is any action they can take over Hillary Clinton's email practices while secretary of state
column2: saying it appeared she had received preferential treatment from the FBI.Ryan
column3: a Republican

column1: Senate Republican leaders said they thought Clinton's testimony to the FBI should be released to the public. But Senate Democratic leader Harry Reid dismissed as political the Republican calls for Clinton to stop getting classified information.""The Republicans are in such desperate shape because of (Republican presidential candidate Donald) Trump
